body.p:
Louisville January 17th 1863
To his Excellency
Jas F Robinson --

We the undersigned Jury-men who tried Jas,, H. Montgomery at the present term of the Jefferson Circuit Court, for the killing of Gibbs, and for which we found him guilty of manslaughter and sentenced him therefor to two years confinement in the penitentiary of the Commonwealth, do most earnestly recommend him to Executive Clemency

Luther Wilson
W. W. Owen
V, C, Kendall
J, H, McCleary
J. Collins
A, B, Dean
J G Mcgehee
J Nettinger
John Bull
I am apprised that Mr Montgomery case is one for excecutive clemency that he is an industrious man & his to his family would be acceptable to huge number of people who know him

The wife of Mr Montgomery is in deep distress. She begs me to ask a pardon for her husband. I cannot resist her appeal Montgomery has always been a good
and industrious citizen. The law has been vindicated by his conviction and mercy may well intervene & spare him.

This will be handed you by Mrs Montgomery who is the wife of the unfortunate person represented in the foregoing, from the history of the case of Montgomery, as I have it from Bersars & worthy of the highest confidence, and the expression of public sentiment, I doubt not but the exercise of Execuitive clemency will be highly satisfactory

To his Excy
Govr Robinson
Frankfort
Ky
